      • binarySearch

        public static int binarySearch​(int[] data,
                               int target,
                               int start,
                               int end)
        Parameters:
        data - : assumed to be sorted in ascending order
        target - : item to find
        start - : starting index
        end - : ending index (assume start is less than or equal to end)
        Returns:
        an index at which target exists in the array data, -1 if target doesn't exist

      • fastPower

        public static int fastPower​(int x,
                            int n)
        Parameters:
        x -
        n -
        Returns:
        x to the power of n. should have O(log n) complexity, not O(n) complexity

      • fastFibonacci

        public static int fastFibonacci​(int n)
        fibonacci sequence is a sequence where the first two terms are 0 and 1 and every subsequent term is the sum of the two terms before it
        Parameters:
        n -
        Returns:
        term at index n in fibonacci sequence. should have O(n) complexity HINT: use lookup tables. fibLookupTable is created as a static variable for you to use FOR EXAMPLE, fastFibonacci(0) = 0 fastFibonacci(1) = 1 fastFibonacci(3) = 2 fastFibonacci(6) = 8 fastFibonacci(8) = 21

      • veryFastFibonacci

        public static java.math.BigInteger veryFastFibonacci​(int n)
        Do the same but with O(log n) complexity? "How?". Research.

      • getPermutation

        public static java.lang.String getPermutation​(int n,
                                              int k)
        Parameters:
        n -
        k -
        Returns:
        (better explained with an example) return null if n is 0 or k is less than 0 or k is more than or equal to factorial(n) Say n = 5 Create a String "12345" (using helper getString) The list of permutations in lexicographic order are: "12345" (k=0) "12354" (k=1) "12435" (k=2) "12453" (k=3) "12534" (k=4) "12543" (k=5) "13245" (k=6) "13254" (k=7) ... return the permutation at index k

      • getPermutation

        public static java.lang.String getPermutation​(java.lang.String s,
                                              int k)

      • factorial

        public static int factorial​(int n)

      • getString

        public static java.lang.String getString​(int n)

      • split53

        public static boolean split53​(int[] data)
        Parameters:
        data -
        Returns:
        true if it is possible to divide the items of the array into two groups, so that the sum of the two groups is the same, with these constraints: all the values that are multiple of 5 must be in one group, and all the values that are a multiple of 3 (and not a multiple of 5) must be in the other. For example: split53(new int[]{3, 5, 6, 10, 3, 3}) = true (group 1 being: 5 and 10 - adding up to 15, group 2 being: 3, 6, 3 and 3 - adding up to 15) other combinations may also exist, but one is enough split53(new int[]{1, 10, 100, 1000}) = false easy to see why

      • split53Helper

                                    int start,
                                    int mult5,
                                    int mult3)
